awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Intern Experiences and Pathways to Labor Market Entry
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1602772
Steven Lopez
Corey Pech
Ohio State University

Internships have become a ubiquitous component of job training. Gaining an understanding of when interns are exploited, and when they are valued, is essential to understanding labor market entry. Previous studies of internships focus on industry case studies. This dissertation is the first comparative study of majors and internship sites to address the question -- under what conditions are internships precarious work and under what conditions are they a stepping stone to a career?  Answering this question has application to both the social sciences and national discourse about the economy, speaking to issues salient to policymakers, corporations, and a concerned citizenry. This project will help individuals and institutions make better decisions about utilizing internships. 

This study makes use of a longitudinal interview research design with two waves of interviews.  Wave one involves interviewing college seniors in four majors about their internships. These are Business/Operations and Logistics; Industrial Engineering; English; and Communications.  Wave two follows up one year later. This design links internship to college major and labor market entry. This study makes contributions to the sociology of work, economic sociology, and the sociology of education. Precarity and insecurity of work is a much-discussed topic in the sociology of work. This study will examine how interns are used by employers and the effects of their labor process on interns' experiences and outcomes. In theory less precarity should increase chances in the labor market, but economic sociology suggests other factors might be more important than the content of the internship. This study will add to knowledge on how non-labor process factor, such social networks or sociability with coworkers, affect internship experiences and outcomes. This study can also make contributions to the sociology of education. Competing theories on labor market entry such as whether majors build human capital or act as a screening device will be adjudicated by this research.

por.por_cntn:
Corey Pech successfully completed data collection and analysis for his dissertation project with the support of an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. The dissertation is a qualitative study of how internships differentially prepare college students for the labor market. The research design is a longitudinal interview project, in which 91 seniors in college, across four majors, were interviewed about their educational and internship experiences. Eighty-six of the ninety-one respondents were retained for the second wave of interviews one year later, creating a total sample of 177 interviews. Wave two interviews covered respondents? labor market transitions and entry level work experiences. NSF support was utilized to pay respondents for participating in the study, for hiring a professional transcription service to transcribe the interviews, and finally to hire an undergraduate research assistant to aid in data organization and analysis.

Results from this research shows that students have differential access to internships that lead to smooth labor market transitions based on their college field of study. Interviewees who were Business or Engineering majors were often recruited into internships that had a pipeline in place for hiring them full-time after graduation. Communications and English majors only rarely had access to similar kinds of internships. Internship experiences matter beyond differences in employment rates and remuneration. Students with smooth labor market transitions via internships had an easier time adjusting to post-college life and had more concrete aspirations. Results also show that there are not large skills differences between the students by field of study. English and Communications student often explained how they used hard skills they learned in the classroom at their internships and entry level jobs. Meanwhile, Business and Engineering majors often spoke of their degrees as providing liberal arts competencies, such as critical thinking, when discussing how their degrees are relevant for their internships and employment tasks. 

The project has generated intellectual merit by engaging theories of the school-to-work transition, and by uncovering a mechanism that creates inequality between students in institutions of higher education. Extant literature has shown how Business and STEM majors earn more money than their liberal arts colleagues, have lower unemployment rates, and are more likely to find a job matched to their degree. However, the mechanisms behind these processes are not well understood. This dissertation shows how labor market devaluation of the liberal arts partially derives from differential access to internships. Internships students have access to are largely related to sector characteristics of potential employers. Therefore, results indicate that labor market organization is paramount to explaining why some college graduates are more employable than others in the contemporary labor market. 

This dissertation research also has broader impacts for society. Findings have been shared with undergraduate students and many undergraduates were utilized as research assistants throughout this dissertation project. Corey Pech also disseminated findings at the American Sociological Association annual meeting and the Midwest Sociology of Education Conference. Additionally, many higher education practitioners are concerned with the employment disparities between practical arts and liberal arts students. The conclusion of the dissertation includes recommendations for how to better improve the internship experiences, and employment outcomes, of liberal arts majors. Currently the first paper from the dissertation is being drafted for submission to a peer-reviewed journal. The entire dissertation is outlined and will serve as the basis of a book manuscript upon completion of the dissertation.
